modules.title: 1.1 The Core HTML Structure
modules.content:
HTML (HyperText Markup Language) provides the structure for all web pages.

Essential Elements:

  • <!DOCTYPE html>: Always first. Defines the document type and standard (HTML5).
  • <html>: The root element, containing everything else.
  • <head>: Contains metadata (non-visible data like the page title and links to CSS/JS).
  • <body>: Contains the visible content of the page (text, images, links).
modules.sample: <!DOCTYPE html> <html lang="en"> <head> <meta charset="UTF-8"> <title>My First Page</title> </head> <body> <h1>Hello World</h1> </body> </html>

modules.title: 1.2 Text, Headings & Attributes
modules.content:
Headings and paragraphs give your content hierarchy.

Formatting Tags:

  • <h1> to <h6>: Headings. Use them to structure your document's outline.
  • <p>: Paragraphs.
  • <strong>: Importance (usually bold).
  • <em>: Emphasis (usually italic).

Attributes:

Attributes provide extra information about an element, usually in the opening tag, like <p class="highlight">.
modules.sample: <h1>Main Title</h1> <p class="intro"> This is a <strong>strong</strong> paragraph. <h3>Sub-section</h3> <p> This text has <em>emphasis</em>. </p>

modules.title: 1.3 Block vs. Inline Elements (DIV & SPAN)
modules.content:
The fundamental difference in HTML layout comes down to two display types: **Block** and **Inline**.

Block Elements (e.g., <div>, <p>):

  • Always start on a new line and take up the full width available.
  • Used for major structural components.
  • **Example:** The <div> is the most common generic block container.

Inline Elements (e.g., <span>, <a>):

  • Only take up as much width as necessary.
  • Do not force line breaks.
  • **Example:** The <span> is the most common generic inline container, often used to style a small piece of text within a paragraph.
modules.sample: <div id="container"> <p> The whole sentence is block-level, but we can highlight a <span style="color: red;">single word</span> as an inline element (only takes necessary width). </p> </div>

modules.title: 1.4 Defining Character Set (<meta charset>)
modules.content: The <meta charset="UTF-8"> tag, placed in the `<head>`, specifies the character encoding for the document, ensuring symbols and international characters are displayed correctly.
modules.sample: <meta charset="UTF-8">

modules.title: 1.5 The HTML Comment Tag
modules.content: Comments (`<!-- ... -->`) are ignored by the browser and are used to leave notes for developers within the code.
modules.sample: <!-- This is a comment -->

modules.title: 1.6 Empty vs. Container Elements
modules.content: **Container** elements have both opening and closing tags and wrap content (e.g., `<p>`). **Empty** elements are self-closing and hold no content (e.g., `<br>`).
modules.sample:
Container: <p>...</p>
Empty: <br>

modules.title: 1.7 Correct Tag Nesting
modules.content: Tags must be closed in the opposite order of how they were opened. For example: `<b><i>text</i></b>` is correct, but `<b><i>text</b></i>` is incorrect.
modules.sample: <b><i>text</i></b>

modules.title: Game: Tag Matcher
modules.instructions: Match the opening tag to its closing tag to make a valid element. Match three pairs to continue!

modules.title: 1.8 Self-Closing Tags (<br>, <hr>)
modules.content: Tags like `<br>` (line break) and `<hr>` (horizontal rule) do not need separate closing tags because they don't wrap content. They are sometimes written as `<br/>` for XML compatibility.
modules.sample: Line 1<br>Line 2<hr>

modules.title: 1.9 Whitespace and Readability
modules.content: HTML ignores extra spaces, tabs, and line breaks in the code (whitespace). Use consistent indentation to make your code easier for humans to read.
modules.sample: Example of proper indentation.

modules.title: 1.10 The Basic Document Template
modules.content: Putting the essential tags together: `<!DOCTYPE>`, `<html>`, `<head>`, `<body>`.
modules.sample: <!DOCTYPE html> <html> <head>...</head> <body>...</body> </html>

modules.title: Did You Know? XHTML Strictness
modules.content: Before HTML5, there was XHTML, which required every tag to be closed and all attributes to be lowercase. HTML5 is much more forgiving!

modules.title: Did You Know? The Meaning of Metadata
modules.content: Metadata literally means "data about data." In the `<head>`, it's information about the HTML document itself, like its title or description.

modules.title: 2.1 Unordered Lists: <ul> and <li>
modules.content: The <ul> element creates an unordered (bulleted) list. Each item inside must be an <li> (list item) element.
modules.sample: <ul> <li>Item 1</li> <li>Item 2</li> </ul>

modules.title: 2.2 Ordered Lists: <ol> and <li>
modules.content:
The <ol> element creates an ordered (numbered or lettered) list. Like `

    `, it uses the <li> element for its items.
modules.sample: <ol> <li>First Step</li> <li>Second Step</li> </ol>

modules.title: 2.3 Nested Lists
modules.content:
You can create sub-lists by placing a complete `

    ` or `
      ` inside an `
    1. ` element of the parent list.
modules.sample: <li>Parent<ul><li>Child</li></ul></li>

modules.title: 2.4 The Anchor Tag: <a>
modules.content: The <a> tag is the Anchor element, used to create hyperlinks to other pages or resources.
modules.sample: <a>Click Here</a>

modules.title: 2.5 The 'href' Attribute (Destination)
modules.content: The href (Hypertext Reference) attribute is mandatory for the `` tag and specifies the destination URL or path.
modules.sample: <a href="/about.html">About Us</a>

modules.title: 2.6 Absolute vs. Relative Paths
modules.content: **Absolute** paths use a full URL (`https://...`). **Relative** paths use a path from the current file's location (`./styles/main.css`).
modules.sample: <a href="https://google.com">External Link</a>

modules.title: 2.7 Linking to a New Tab (`target='_blank'`)
modules.content: Using the target="_blank" attribute in an `<a>` tag will force the linked document to open in a new browser tab or window.
modules.sample: <a href="sample.com" target="_blank">link</a>

modules.title: 2.8 Linking to IDs (Internal Links)
modules.content: You can link to an element on the same page by setting the `href` attribute to `#` followed by the target element's `id` (e.g., `<a href="#top">`).
modules.sample: <a href="#footer">Go to Footer</a>

modules.title: 2.9 Linking to Email (`mailto:`)
modules.content: Starting the `href` with mailto: will open the user's default email client, pre-filled with the specified address.
modules.sample: <a href="mailto:contact@example.com">Email Us</a>

modules.title: 2.10 Linking to Phone (`tel:`)
modules.content: Starting the `href` with tel: allows mobile users to initiate a phone call directly from the link.
modules.sample: <a href="tel:+15551234">Call Us</a>

modules.title: Did You Know? Anchor Names
modules.content: The `<a>` tag is called the Anchor element because it 'anchors' two web pages together or 'anchors' a link to a specific spot on the page (an ID).

modules.title: Did You Know? Default Link Styles
modules.content: By default, unvisited links are blue and underlined, and visited links are purple and underlined. You can change this behavior entirely using CSS.

modules.title: 3.1 The Image Tag: <img>
modules.content: The <img> element is used to embed an image into the document. It is a self-closing tag.
modules.sample: <img>

modules.title: 3.2 The Image 'src' Attribute
modules.content: TThe src (source) attribute is mandatory for `<img>` and specifies the file path (absolute or relative) to the image you want to display.
modules.sample: <img src="https://encrypted-tbn0.gstatic.com/images?q=tbn:ANd9GcSr2P3WUR7icDEP3Q3oXSA2zn_emcmCtWOJdg&s" />

modules.title: 3.3 The Image 'alt' Attribute
modules.content: The alt (alternate text) attribute is mandatory for accessibility. It provides a descriptive text if the image fails to load, or for screen readers.
modules.sample: <img src="https://encrypted-tbn0.gstatic.com/images?q=tbn:ANd9GcSr2P3WUR7icDEP3Q3oXSA2zn_emcmCtWOJdg&s" alt="Sample Image" />

modules.title: 3.4 Setting Image Width and Height
modules.content: You can use the width and height attributes (in pixels) directly on the `<img>` tag to reserve space and prevent layout shifts.
modules.sample: <img src="https://encrypted-tbn0.gstatic.com/images?q=tbn:ANd9GcSr2P3WUR7icDEP3Q3oXSA2zn_emcmCtWOJdg&s" alt="A picture" width="100" height="50">

modules.title: 3.5 Making an Image a Link
modules.content: To make an image clickable, simply wrap the entire `<img>` tag inside an `<a>` tag.
modules.sample: <a href="/home"><img src="https://encrypted-tbn0.gstatic.com/images?q=tbn:ANd9GcSr2P3WUR7icDEP3Q3oXSA2zn_emcmCtWOJdg&s" alt="Sample Image Link"></a>

modules.title: 3.6 Figure and Figcaption
modules.content: The <figure> tag groups media content (like an image), and <figcaption> provides a caption or explanatory description for that media.
modules.sample: <figure><img src="https://encrypted-tbn0.gstatic.com/images?q=tbn:ANd9GcSr2P3WUR7icDEP3Q3oXSA2zn_emcmCtWOJdg&s" alt="A photo with caption" /><figcaption>A caption.</figcaption></figure>

modules.title: 3.7 Introduction to Video <video>
modules.content: The <video> tag is used to embed video content. The `controls` attribute displays the browser's default play/pause and volume controls.
modules.sample: <video controls src="video.mp4">Your browser does not support the video tag.</video>

modules.title: 3.8 Introduction to Audio <audio>
modules.content: The <audio> tag is used to embed audio content into the page. Like video, it often includes the `controls` attribute.
modules.sample: <audio controls src="sound.mp3">Your browser does not support the audio element.</audio>

modules.title: 3.9 Image File Types (PNG vs. JPEG)
modules.content: **JPEG** is best for complex photographs. **PNG** is better for images with sharp lines, text, or transparency.
modules.sample: File types explained.

modules.title: 3.10 Vector Graphics (SVG Intro)
modules.content: **SVG** (Scalable Vector Graphics) is an XML-based image format that scales perfectly at any size without losing quality, ideal for logos and icons.
modules.sample: Example of an .svg file.

modules.title: Did You Know? Importance of 'alt'
modules.content: Screen readers for visually impaired users rely entirely on the `alt` text to describe what an image is about. If it is missing, the image is invisible to them.

modules.title: Did You Know? Video Autoplay
modules.content: Most modern browsers prevent videos with sound from autoplaying without user interaction to improve the browsing experience.

modules.title: 4.1 The Generic Block Container: <div>
modules.content: The <div> (division) is the most common block-level container, used to group larger sections of code for styling (CSS) or manipulation (JavaScript).
modules.sample: <div class="main-section">...</div>

modules.title: 4.2 The Generic Inline Container: <span>
modules.content: The <span> element is the most common inline container, used to target a small piece of text *within* a block-level element for minor styling.
modules.sample: <span style="color: red;">red text</span>

modules.title: 4.3 Introduction to Semantic HTML
modules.content: Semantic HTML means using tags that clearly define their content's purpose (e.g., `<nav>` for navigation, not just a `<div>`). This helps search engines and accessibility tools.
modules.sample: Definition of semantics.

modules.title: 4.4 The <header> Tag
modules.content: The <header> tag is used for introductory content, often containing a logo, site title, and navigation links.
modules.sample: <header>...</header>

modules.title: 4.5 The <nav> Tag
modules.content: The <nav> tag is used to wrap major navigation links for a document or section.
modules.sample: <nav><ul>...</ul></nav>

modules.title: 4.6 The <main> Tag
modules.content: The <main> tag contains the dominant content of the document, excluding headers, footers, and sidebars. It should only appear once per page.
modules.sample: <main>...</main>

modules.title: 4.7 The <section> Tag
modules.content: The <section> tag groups thematic content, typically with a heading. Examples include a News section or a Contact Info section.
modules.sample: <section>...</section>

modules.title: 4.8 The <article> Tag
modules.content: The <article> tag is used for self-contained content that could be distributed independently, like a blog post or a newspaper article.
modules.sample: <article>...</article>

modules.title: 4.9 The <aside> Tag
modules.content: The <aside> tag is used for content that is tangentially related to the main content, like sidebars, pull-quotes, or advertisements.
modules.sample: <aside>...</aside>

modules.title: 4.10 The <footer> Tag
modules.content: The <footer> tag is used for content at the bottom of a document or section, typically containing copyright information, contact info, or related links.
modules.sample: <footer>...</footer>

modules.title: Did You Know? Div Soup
modules.content: Before semantic HTML5, developers often built layouts using many nested `<div>` tags with classes (e.g., `<div class="header">`). This was jokingly referred to as 'div soup.'

modules.title: Did You Know? Single Main
modules.content: Unlike other semantic tags, the `<main>` element must not be used more than once in a document and should not be a descendant of `<article>`, `<aside>`, `<footer>`, `<header>`, or `<nav>`.

modules.title: 5.1 The 'class' Attribute (Styling Hook)
modules.content: The class attribute is a reusable identifier used to group multiple elements for the purpose of applying CSS styles (e.g., all elements with `class="warning"`).
modules.sample: <p class="text-center">Centered Text</p>

modules.title: 5.2 The 'id' Attribute (Unique Hook)
modules.content: The id attribute is a unique identifier used to target a *single* element for linking (e.g., `<a href="#id">`) or for JavaScript manipulation.
modules.sample: <div id="main-button">Clickable Area</div>

modules.title: 5.3 Classes vs. IDs
modules.content: Use **classes** when you want to style many elements the same way. Use **IDs** when you need a single, unique identifier for a specific element (e.g., a modal or a main heading).
modules.sample: Comparison of use cases.

modules.title: 5.4 The 'style' Attribute (Inline CSS)
modules.content: The style attribute allows you to apply CSS properties directly to an individual HTML element, though this is generally discouraged for large projects.
modules.sample: <p style="color: blue;">Blue Text</p>

modules.title: 5.5 Global Attributes (Accesskey, Hidden)
modules.content: Global attributes are attributes that can be used on *every* HTML element. Examples include `class`, `id`, `style`, and `hidden` (which hides an element from view).
modules.sample: <p hidden>Secret Text</p>

modules.title: 5.6 The 'data-' Attributes
modules.content: Custom `data-*` attributes allow you to embed custom data privately into the HTML. This data can be easily accessed and modified using JavaScript.
modules.sample: <button data-user-id="123">User Info</button>

modules.title: 5.7 Basic Tables: <table>
modules.content: The <table> element is used to structure data into rows and columns, like a spreadsheet.
modules.sample: <table>...</table>

modules.title: 5.8 Table Rows and Data (<tr>, <td>)
modules.content: Table structure relies on <tr> (table row) and <td> (table data/cell). Every row must contain one or more data cells.
modules.sample: <tr><td>Cell 1</td></tr>

modules.title: 5.9 Table Headers (<th>)
modules.content: The <th> (table header) element defines a header cell in a table. By default, content is bold and centered.
modules.sample: <tr><th>Header Name</th></tr>

modules.title: 5.10 Table Structure (<thead>, <tbody>)
modules.content: For better semantics, tables are often split into <thead> (header section) and <tbody> (body section).
modules.sample: <table><thead>...</thead><tbody>...</tbody></table>

modules.title: Did You Know? The 'style' War
modules.content: Inline `style` attributes were necessary before CSS was widely adopted. Now, they are generally only used for very specific, dynamic changes made by JavaScript.

modules.title: Did You Know? Tables for Layout
modules.content: In the 90s and early 2000s, developers frequently used `<table>` tags to structure *entire page layouts*. This is now obsolete; modern layout is done using CSS (like Flexbox and Grid).
